Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Intraarticular Fibrinogen in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive intraarticular fibrinogen or no treatment before tourniquet release.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive intraarticular fibrinogen or no treatment before tourniquet release.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the efficacy of intraarticular fibrinogen in reducing bleeding and transfusion needs post-TKA.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative blood loss, assessed by drain output and hemoglobin drop at Day 2.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 100 patients were allocated to each group, with analysis conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 100 patients were allocated to each group, with analysis conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Mean drain output was 780 ± 378 mL in the fibrinogen group versus 673 ± 301 mL in the control group (p = 0.029).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were comparable between groups.
